notes: Compact crossover on Model 3 platform. Best-selling EV globally. Available in RWD, Long Range AWD, and Performance configurations. 75-82 kWh battery pack. 400V architecture. Over-the-air updates. Autopilot standard. High-voltage EV system requires EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model Y article, January 2025 revision.

Major refresh with new interior design (yoke steering wheel option). Plaid variant with tri-motor produces 1,020 hp, 0-60 mph in 1.99 seconds. 100 kWh battery pack. 400V architecture. 405-mile range (Long Range). 396-mile range (Plaid). High-voltage systems require specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model S article, January 2025 revision.

Major refresh matching Model S updates. Falcon-wing rear doors. Plaid tri-motor produces 1,020 hp. 100 kWh battery pack. 400V architecture. Three-row seating for 6-7. 348-mile range (Long Range). 333-mile range (Plaid). High-voltage complexity requires EV-certified service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model X article, January 2025 revision.

engines: EV Dual Motor AWD Long Range (366 hp)
notes: Major refresh (Project Highland) with updated exterior, interior, and improved efficiency. Revised front/rear design. 60-82 kWh battery pack options. 400V architecture. Enhanced suspension. Best-selling EV sedan. High-voltage systems require EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Model 3 article, January 2025 revision.

engines: EV Single Motor RWD (~600 hp, planned)
notes: Revolutionary stainless steel exoskeleton design. 800V architecture (48V low-voltage). Tri-motor Cyberbeast produces 845 hp. Adaptive air suspension. Steer-by-wire. Up to 340-mile range. Bulletproof stainless steel body panels. 800V high-voltage system and unique construction require highly specialized service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Cybertruck article, January 2025 revision.

Class 8 electric semi-truck. Quad-motor powertrain. 500-mile range configuration. 300-mile range option. Megawatt charging capability. 0-60 mph in 20 seconds (loaded). Designed for commercial trucking. Limited production/pilot deliveries. Commercial EV complexity requires specialized heavy-duty EV service expertise. Data sourced from Wikipedia Tesla Semi article, January 2025 revision.
